Description: A diagnosis is the result of a medical investigation to identify a disorder from its signs and symptoms.
Valid Values: Parkinson's Disease, control, melanoma, asthma, multiple sclerosis, depression, endometriosis, sleep related disorder

Description: A bronchial disease that is characterized by chronic inflammation and narrowing of the airways, which is caused by a combination of environmental and genetic factors. The disease has_symptom recurring periods of wheezing (a whistling sound while breathing), has_symptom chest tightness, has_symptom shortness of breath, has_symptom mucus production and has_symptom coughing. The symptoms appear due to a variety of triggers such as allergens, irritants, respiratory infections, weather changes, exercise, stress, reflux disease, medications, foods and emotional anxiety.
An individual who is or becomes a participant in a research study and has no significant health-related issues related to the study at hand.
Low mood and/or loss of interest or pleasure in normally enjoyable activities.
A female reproductive system disease characterized by the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterine body.
A cell type cancer that has_material_basis_in abnormally proliferating cells derives_from melanocytes which are found in skin, the bowel and the eye.
A demyelinating disease that involves damage to the fatty myelin sheaths around the axons of the brain and spinal cord resulting in demyelination and scarring.
A synucleinopathy that has_material_basis_in degeneration of the central nervous system that often impairs motor skills, speech, and other functions.
An abnormality of sleep which may such phenomena as insomnia/hypersomnia, non-restorative sleep, sleep schedule disorder, excessive daytime somnolence, sleep apnea, and/or restlessness.

Description: A tremor present when the limbs are active, either when outstretched in a certain position or throughout a voluntary movement.
The ability of the heart and lungs to deliver blood and oxygen to the tissues during aerobic activity. It is a general measure of the relative conditioning of the heart and respiratory system.
Relating to the heart and blood vescles.

The mental processes involved in gaining knowledge and comprehension. Cognitive processes include thinking, knowing, remembering, judging, and problem-solving. These are higher-level functions of the brain and encompass language, imagination, perception, and planning.
Traits involving the skin, hair and/or nails.
A pattern or manner of running, walking, or moving on foot.
Emotional, psychological, and social well-being of an individual or group.
The ability to move or be moved freely and easily.
A relatively temporary state of feeling.
The combination of body movements created with the kinematic (such as spatial direction) and kinetic (force) parameters that result in intended actions.
Degree of commitment and participation of a study subject.
The process of producing vocal sounds by vibration of the vocal cords during an expiration of air.
A measurement of a subject's physical activity or movement.
A type of tremors that is triggered by holding a limb in a fixed position.
The standard of health, comfort, well-being, and happiness experienced by an individual or group.
Relating to the respiratory system.
A resting tremor occurs when muscles are at rest and becomes less noticeable or disappears when the affected muscles are moved. Resting tremors are often slow and coarse.
Color or darkness/lightness of skin.
Related to the natural and periodic state of rest during which consciousness of the world is suspended.
Specific activities performed during digital assessments.
An assessment of cardiorespiratory fitness in which the subject runs or walks at full capacity for 12 minutes. The resulting distance has been shown to be correlated with VO2max.
A test of simple reaction time (RT) to stimuli that occur at random intervals and therefore measures vigilant attention.

A standardized rating scale developed by Bruno Blake in 1963, which is a performance-based evaluation of functional exercise capacity in subjects with chronic respiratory disease and heart failure, as well as other populations such as healthy older adults and people suffering from fibromyalgia and scleroderma. This functional test contains 6 items and measures the distance an individual is able to walk over a total of six minutes on a hard, flat surface.
A quantity sample type that measures the amount of active energy the user has burned.

Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Motor examination; rapid alternating movements of hands (Pronation-supination movements of hands, vertically and horizontally, with as large an amplitude as possible, both hands simultaneously.).
A motor task requiring subjects to arrange sheets of paper in a folder.
A motor task requiring subjects to assemble nuts and bolts.
Passive monitoring during a subject's normal daily activity.
A quantity of distance a subject has moved
A motor task requiring subjects to draw or write.
The amount of time that the user has spent exercising during the specified day.
Assessment of facial skin pigmentation against a standardized scale.
Assessment of skin pigmentation on the finger against a standardized scale.
A motor task as follows. The subject starts with the arm in an outstretched position, bends at the elbow to touch their nose with their fingers, then returns to the starting position
A quantity sample type that measures the number flights of stairs that the user has climbed
A motor task in which the subject folds towels.
The number of heartbeats per unit of time, usually expressed as beats per minute.
A memory assessment task in with the subject matches shapes hidden under tiles.

Attribute: opening a water bottle and pouring
Description: A motor task in which the subject opens a bottle of water and pours the contents into a glass.
A task in which the subject attempts to produce a constant "aaaaaaa" sound.
Photograph of the subject or a specific body part.
A state in which the subject is not moving.
A quantity sample type that measures the resting energy burned by the user.
The act of assuming or maintaining a seated position.
The act of assuming or maintaining an erect upright position.
A quantity sample type that measures the number of steps the user has taken.
A question or series of questions.
An activity in which fingers or other body parts tap a surface repeatedly.
An assessment of cardiorespiratory fitness in which the subject steps up and down on a bench or step for 3-minutes.
A graded test to measure an individual's heart rate and oxygen intake while undergoing strenuous physical exercise; most often assessed on a treadmill.
A motor task in which the subject types on a keyboard.

An assessment used to identify individuals with neurological impairment, as well as to assess divided attention, visual scanning and motor speed. This functional test measures the time to pair abstract symbols with specific numbers with a fixed time. Scoring of this test is based on the total number of correctly coded items in the alloted time.
Walking task on a flat surface.
Walking up or down stairs.

Description: A report describing the amount or quality of activities performed.
A report describing subject's management of asthma symptoms.
A report describing the frequency, duration and/or quality of asthma symptoms.
A report describing triggers of asthmatic symptoms.

A standardized rating scale developed by the World Health Organization (WHO), which is a modified version of the original Alcohol Use Disorder Identification Test (AUDIT). The questionnaire contains 3 questions, and is used to identify patients who are hazardous drinkers or have active alcohol use disorders.
The pressure of the circulating blood against the walls of the blood vessels.
Report describing bradykinesia, a hypokinesia characterized by an extreme slowness in the execution of movements and reflexes.
The determination of the amount of total cholesterol present in a sample.
A report describing subject demographics such as age, sex, etc.
A report describing diabetes diagnoses, symptoms or related phenotypes.
A report describing characteristics of food consumed.
A report assessing risk for a particular disease.
A report of distance, usually related to a physical activity such as walking, running or biking.
A report describing dyskinesia, a movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.

The EuroQol (European Quality of Life) Five Dimension questionaire, which asks a patient to rate their health with respect to mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort and anxiety/depression.
Family history is a form of clinicaly history specifically about relevant aspects of genetic preconditions or family member's clinical history.

A quantitative measurement of the amount of glucose present in a sample of blood, obtained from a source that has abstained from nutrition, typically at least 8 hours prior to the sample collection time.
A survey describing a subject's experience in a study.
A survey administered after the close of a study.
A report describing freezing of gait symptoms, a brief, episodic absence or marked reduction of forward progression of the feet despite the intention to walk.

Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 Questionnaire, a seven item validated, self-reported questionnaire for screening, and assessing the severity of generalized anxiety disorder in clinical practice and research settings.
An assessment of risk for heart attack or stroke based on factors such as age, blood pressure, cholesterol, as well as lifestyle.
The distance from the sole to the crown of the head with body standing on a flat surface and fully extended.
A report related to high blood pressure or chronic high blood pressure.
A survey to assess a subject's qualification for a study.
Results of one or more sections of the The Movement Disorder Society version of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) assessment.
A report about a subject's medical history.
A report or log of medication intake.
An assessment of mole size.
A report of mole location.
A report about whether or not a mole has been surgically removed.
A report about a subject's mood or emotional state.
The subdomain of the Quality of Life in Neurological Disorders (Neuro-QoL) survey that assess perceived difficulties in cognitive abilities related to both executive function and general concerns.

The subdomain of the Quality of Life in Neurological Disorders (Neuro-QoL) survey that assess perceived difficulties in ability to carry out various activities involving digital, manual and reach-related functions, ranging from fine motor to self-care (activities of daily living).

The subdomain of the Quality of Life in Neurological Disorders (Neuro-QoL) survey that assess perceived difficulties in ability to carry out various activities involving the trunk region and increasing degrees of bodily movement, ambulation, balance or endurance.
National Academy of Sports Medicine Physical Activity Readiness Questionaire.
Parkinson's Disease Questionnaire, 8 question version.
A report about phone usage.
Patient Health Questionnaire-2, a 2-item scale used to screen for depression and anhedonia over the past 2 weeks. It is comprised of the first 2 items of the Patient Health Questionnaire-9.

Patient Health Questionnaire-9, a 9-item scale using each of the 9 DSM-IV criteria for depression with self-reported frequency of "0" (not at all) to "3" (nearly every day). One of the most widely used instruments to assess depression, PHQ-9 scores of 5, 10, 15, and 20 represent mild, moderate, moderately severe, and severe depression, respectively.
A non-specific report about subject quality of life.
A report describing a relapse event.
A report about the study participant and their interest in participating in research studies.
Heart rate measurement while a subject is at rest.
A report about the duration and/or quality of sleep.
An activity report that quantifies the number of steps taken.
A report about presence, duration or severity of symptoms.
A report describing tremor, a generial symptom characterized by a trembling or shaking usually from physical weakness, emotional stress, or disease.
A report describing triggers for symptoms.
A physiological assay to determine the maximum capacity of an individual's body to transport and use oxygen during incremental exercise, which reflects the physical fitness of the individual.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual.
A report of location in the form of postal code.

Description: Metadata describing the properties of a clinical or digital health assessment.
Metadata describing terms or variables that appear in another file.

Metadata describing properties of individuals (human or animal) represented in the study.

Study or collection type
Valid Values: Observational Study, Interventional Study, Validation Study, Analysis, Challenge

Description: An observational study is a quantitative study in which the investigators do not seek to intervene, and simply observe the course of events.

An interventional study is a quantitative study that prospectively assigns human participants or groups of humans to one or more health-related interventions to evaluate the effects on health outcomes. Interventions include but are not restricted to drugs, cells and other biological products, surgical procedures, radiologic procedures, devices, behavioural treatments, process-of-care changes, preventive care, etc.
A validation study is a quantitative study that seeks to assess the validity of a measurement against a "gold standard" or reproduce previous findings.
Derivation of features or findings from a study or experiment.
Crowd-sourced effort to benchmark analysis methods.

A process or action that is the focus of a study. Interventions include drugs, medical devices, procedures, vaccines, and other products that are either investigational or already available. Interventions can also include noninvasive approaches, such as education or modifying diet and exercise.
Valid Values: levodopa

Description: Medical treatment which is a precursor to dopamine. Most commonly, clinicians use levodopa as a dopamine replacement agent for the treatment of Parkinson disease.
PI or organization responsible for running the study.
Boolean describing whether the Synapse project contains a Study (e.g. mPower, Elevate MS, etc) or a Project (i.e. an analysis of data from one or more studies).
Valid Values: TRUE, FALSE

Description: Any file derived from or pertaining to a scientific experiment. experimentalData annotations should be applied, possibly disease-related
Any file derived from or pertaining a manually or programatically curated data resource. Examples include: reference sequences, drug information databases, identifier maps
Any file derived from analysis such that the analysis annotations might apply, possibly disease-related
Any file or link that represents a tool, model, or algorithm; the tool annotations could be applied

a document assembled by an author for the purpose of providing information for the audience. A report is the output of a documenting process and has the objective to be consumed by a specific audience. Topic of the report is on something that has completed. A report is not a single figure. Examples of reports are journal article, patent application, grant progress report, case report (not patient record).
A collaborative data analysis in the form of an open community challenge.
Level of data available in the Study/Project
Valid Values: processed, raw

Description: Data that has undergone some processing procedure. Not fully raw.
Unprocessed data from a sensor.
